    Before a trial can begin, the attorneys must select a jury. During the trial, witnesses may testify and evidence will be presented. At the conclusion of the trial, the jury must decide if the defendant is guilty or not guilty. If the jury finds the defendant is not guilty, he or she is released and cannot be tried again for the same crime. If the defendant is found guilty, the case will be continued for sentencing, or the defendant may be sentenced immediately.

  • Court Trial

    In lieu of a jury trial, the defendant may agree to proceed with a court trial, in which the judge hears the evidence and arguments and finds the defendant guilty or not guilty.

Failure to Appear

If you fail to appear in court as promised/ordered, the court may order and issue a warrant for your arrest. The prosecuting agency may also ask the court to add additional charges against you for failing to appear. Further, you may be punished by jail and/or a fine, regardless of the disposition of the original charge. In addition, the Department of Motor Vehicles may withhold issuance or renewal or your driver's license and may revoke or suspend your driving privilege. The failure to appear hold on your driver’s license will be released upon your appearance in court.

Fines

If the court orders a fine, additional Penalty Assessments may be added.

Fines may be paid by cash, money order, credit card, debit card, or personal check in the Clerk's Office. You may also pay by mail. To ensure your payment is applied to your case, always write your case number on your check or money order. Please do not mail cash. If you would like to request a receipt, you must include a self-addressed stamped envelope.

Jail/Inmate Information

The Shasta County Jail is operated by the Sheriff's Department, not the court. For information regarding inmates and arrested persons, you may call 530-245-6100.

Jurisdiction

The Shasta County Superior Court has jurisdiction over infraction, misdemeanor and felony cases. The Criminal Division handles any complaint filed by a prosecuting agency, including but not limited to the Shasta County District Attorney and the State Attorney General’s Office representing the City of Redding, City of Shasta Lake, Anderson, and Burney.

Legal Representation

Clerks are prohibited by law from giving legal advice. If you are provided legal assistance through the Public Defender's office, or any other court-appointed counsel, the court will make a determination of your ability to pay all or part of the costs. If the court finds that you can pay, it may make an order for you to pay the costs. This order has the same force and effect as a civil judgment. The court may also order that you return for additional hearings to determine your ability to pay the cost of a court-appointed counsel after your case is concluded. If you cannot afford an attorney, the court will appoint one at the time of arraignment if you meet the qualifications.

Name Indexing/Search Fees or to Inquire About a Case

You can search our Case Index online or submit a written request for a criminal background search. The Criminal Clerk’s Office will conduct a name index/name search when requested. Name searches are limited to cases filed within Shasta County. These requests may be made in person at the Criminal Clerk’s Office or through the mail. The information requested may be picked up or returned by mail in a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

Please refer to the current Fee Schedule for name index costs, or contact the Criminal Clerk’s Office for more information.

Name indexing and case disposition information is not provided over the telephone.

Petition for Certificate of Rehabilitation and Pardon

A certificate of rehabilitation is a court order declaring that you have been rehabilitated after a California state criminal conviction. It also recommends that the governor grant you a full pardon. If you are granted a certificate of rehabilitation, the court will send certified copies to the governor. This will serve as an application for a pardon by the governor. A pardon by the governor gives you all the civil and political rights of citizenship, including the right to vote, and, in some cases, the right to own and keep a legal firearm. A certificate of rehabilitation and Governor’s pardon is only available to California residents. You may obtain the forms from our Forms & Filings page (Form Packets Link).

Resources for Help

Further information and publications are available at the California Courts Self Help Center.

Petition for Dismissal

If you were convicted of an infraction, a misdemeanor, or a felony and were NOT sentenced to state prison or put under the authority of the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, you can petition for a dismissal. You are eligible to request a dismissal if you were given county jail time, probation, a fine, or a combination of those three types of punishment rather than being sentenced to state prison. You may file a petition to dismiss if you have fulfilled all terms of probation, or have been discharged from the original term of probation, or have not been placed on probation and your entire sentence terms have been completed, including payment of all fines and fees on the case. If you make a formal request to the court (petition) for a dismissal, the court will make a decision on your request and may withdraw your guilty or no contest (nolo contendere) plea (or the guilty verdict if you went to trial), and enter a not guilty plea. Then the court will set aside and dismiss the conviction. From that point forward, you are no longer considered to be “convicted” of the offense. Your record will be changed to show a dismissal rather than a conviction. You may obtain the forms from our Forms & Filings page (Form Packets Link).

Resources for Help

Further information and publications are available at the California Courts Self Help Center.

Public Records

The public may not have access to an arrest report or any document containing a victim’s name, address, or telephone number.

Photocopies of public records can be requested at the Criminal Clerk’s Office. Please refer to the current Fee Schedule for copy and certification fees.

Record Requests

If you have a case number and you would like copies of the file, submit a written request along with a check with the words "Not To Exceed $25.00" to cover the initial cost of the copies. You will be notified (by mail or phone) should the cost exceed $25.00. Checks and money orders should be made payable to "Shasta County Superior Court". Mail your request to Criminal Clerk’s Office, Attention: Criminal Records. Please include a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

Sheriff's Work Release

The Sheriff's work release is an alternative to continuous confinement in the main jail. Participation in this program is ordered by the court at the time of sentencing, however, the Sheriff's Department determines eligibility. For further information, you may call 530-245-6720.

title: Jury Summons Reporting Instructions
body:
Jury Summons Reporting Instructions

Verify the date below is your date.
This data is updated by 5:00 p.m. daily.
Then find your group number below to determine "your instructions".
For the date of July 18, 2023
Group(s)Instruction
Please be advised the following items are not allowed in the courthouse: knives, scissors, sharp objects, weapons of any kind, pepper spray and glass items, such as bottles, cups, etc.
POSTPONEMENT REQUESTS: Postponement requests MUST be made FIVE (5) BUSINESS DAYS PRIOR to your date of service. To request a postponement via email, please identify your email in the subject line with POSTPONEMENT REQUEST and your BADGE NUMBER. Submit your email to: jury@shasta.courts.ca.gov. To request a postponement via phone, please dial 530-225-5701. Follow the prompts for postponing your juror summons date. If you are unable or ineligible to postpone yourself through the automated phone system, you may contact us at 530-245-6789 and follow the prompts for Jury Service. Due to the high call volume, if no one is available to take your call at that time, you may leave a voice mail message and we will return your call. Please do not leave more than one voice mail message. You may also request a postponement via email, fax, U.S. mail, and/or in person. Requests received on the day of service or within 5 business days of service will be denied UNLESS accompanied with a legal doctors excuse.
Make arrangements for personal matters as you *may be* at the courthouse for a full business day, which could end between 4:30 and 5:00 p.m. Children under 18 are NOT permitted.
PARK IN THE "JURY PARKING" LOT AS SHOWN ON YOUR SUMMONS. BRING YOUR POSTCARD SUMMONS WITH YOU TO THE JURY ASSEMBLY ROOM. Do NOT park in the metered parking, permit or the signed limited parking hours, unless you have a disability placard. JURY SERVICE DOES NOT OVERRIDE THE PARKING METERS. Please plan on arriving early to find adequate parking.
Log on to the "Jury Duty Portal" using the web address for the court: www.shasta.courts.ca.gov/jury to complete your online profile including the section regarding reimbursement for mileage, the daily fee, your email address, and phone number. PLEASE NOTE: You are unable to edit your date of birth. You may also complete the above process in the Jury Assembly Room.
001-046Check this website again AFTER 5:00 p.m. Tuesday, July 18, 2023, for further reporting instructions. NOTE: THIS INFORMATION CHANGES DAILY. Your group number has been put on TELEPHONE STANDBY as your trial is scheduled to begin later this week. Jurors may be placed on standby for up to five (5) court days for use in a trial courtroom. If jurors are not called to serve within that five (5) day period, they will be considered completed for service for a minimum of one (1) year.
047-072Your group number has been continued to a future date. You are NOT on telephone standby and have not yet completed your service. You will receive another summons prior to your new summons date. If you should need to make any corrections to your name and address, please email Jury Services or log on to the Jury Duty Portal.

title: File By E-Mail Request For Domestic Violence Restraining Order And Petition For Gun Violence Restraining Order
body:
File by e-mail Request for Domestic Violence Restraining Order and Petition for Gun Violence Restraining Order


If you are in danger now, dial 911 or seek safety. Please note that websites you visit may be viewed by someone else later. Always clear your browsing history after searching the web. Consider using a public or friend's computer if you are concerned about someone viewing your browsing history.


Filing by e-mail is available for Request for Domestic Violence and Petition for Gun Violence only.

Getting Started:

A Request for DV Restraining Order and Petition for Gun Violence Restraining Order may be filed by e-mail. Your forms need to be in PDF format. Instructions on how to file by e-mail are listed below.


E-mailing a Request for DV Restraining Order and Petition for a Gun Violence Restraining Order is at no cost to you.


If you are representing yourself, we strongly suggest you contact the Self Help Center at (530) 245-6900 or e-mail at selfhelp@shasta.courts.ca.gov before e-mailing your forms for filing. A review of your forms can be done in person or by e-mail. This will ensure you file the correct legal documents to address your specific legal issue. Submitting the wrong paperwork or incomplete paperwork can result in delaying your legal action.


You can find the Domestic Violence and Gun Violence Forms on the Forms Link below.

Forms Link: The Superior Court of California



To file a Request for Domestic Violence Restraining Order you must submit the following documents to initiate a case:


  • DV-100 Request for Domestic Violence Restraining Order
  • DV-109 Notice of Court Hearing
  • DV-110 Temporary Restraining Order (CLETS-TRO)
  • CLETS-001
  • LF-FAM-105 Mandatory Disclosure of Information (Only required if requesting child custody/visitation orders)


    • To file a Petition for Gun Violence Restraining Order you must submit the following documents to initiate a case:


  • GV-100 Petition for Gun Violence Restraining Order
  • GV-109 Notice of Court Hearing
  • GV-110 Temporary Gun Violence Restraining Order (CLETS-TGV)
  • CLETS-001
  • CM-010 Civil Case Cover Sheet


    • Instructions for e-mail filing a request for Domestic Violence and Petition for Gun Violence Restraining Orders:

    Your filings must be complete and readable.


    You must complete as much information regarding the person you are seeking protection from. If you don’t know the person’s exact age, height, or weight, do your best to estimate.

    Make sure you include your phone number and e-mail address so we can contact you if we have any questions.


  • Each document attached to your e-mail must be a separate attachment in a PDF format. Please use the form number as the name of the document.
  • Check your e-mail frequently, if your documents are not complete, we will return them to you to complete and resubmit.
  • Your Restraining Order will be e-mailed to you, if you prefer to receive it through US mail or to pick it up at the Civil Counter, please let us know. Keep in mind, if we send it to you via e-mail you will need to make additional copies for service.

    • Please e-mail your filing for Request for Domestic Violence or Petition for Gun Violence Restraining Order to:

    restrainingorders@shasta.courts.ca.gov


    After Submitting:

    Once you submit your documents filed by e-mail you should receive a confirmation e-mail from the Court that your submission was received. A clerk will then review your forms. After review, you will receive an e-mail accepting or notifying you that your submission was incomplete. The e-mail accepting your submission will have a pdf attachment with a file-stamped copy of your Request/Petition. If your submission is returned for being incomplete, you will be provided with information as to what additional information is needed.

    Resources (links):

  • Domestic Violence Restraining Orders in California | California Courts | Self Help Guide
  • Gun Violence Restraining Orders - abuse_firearms_selfhelp (ca.gov)
  • Can a Domestic Violence Restraining Order Help Me? (Domestic Violence Prevention) (DV-500-INFO)
  • Can a Gun Violence Restraining Order Help Me? (GV-100-INFO)
  • One SAFE Place

title: Court Case Records
body:
Court Case Records

Usage agreement

The information provided on and obtained from this site does not constitute the official record of the Court. This information is provided as a service to the general public. Any user of this information is hereby advised that it is being provided "as is". The information provided may be subject to errors or omissions. The Court maintains this website as a public service to enhance access to public information. This service is continually under development, and it will be updated as events take place and court resources permit.Visitors to this site agree that the Court is not liable for errors or omissions of any of the information provided. Visitors further consent to access the record only as instructed by the Court and consent to the Court's monitoring of access to the records. The Court may deny access to a member of the public for failure to comply with any of these conditions of use.

This website is governed and construed by the laws of the State of California and the California Rules of Court. Any use of the website shall comply with all applicable laws and regulations. Unauthorized attempts to upload information or change information on this portal are strictly prohibited and may be punishable under the laws of the State of California, State Computer Trespass law and federal statutes including the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act of 1986 and the National Information Infrastructure Protection Act, as amended.

Pursuant to California Rules of Court 2.503, the court restricts documents from remote display on certain case type categories identified in this Rule of Court. However, the court records may be available for access and/or viewing at our Records Department locations in the courthouse building located at 1500 Court St., Redding, CA. 96001.

Public Portal

  • Allows login access to registered users.
  • Access to privileged information is for authorized users only. If you have not been granted access to privileged information, you will see the same information as the regular public.
  • Important - If you are an employee of a Justice Partner Agency, you may request elevated access which may allow to you to see additional case information, which may include documents and images. If you are not part of a Justice Partner Agency, you will see the same information as the regular public. Please note, elevated access to case information and documents is currently in progress. The Court has limited resources and will continue adding functionality as time and resources allow.

    • If elevated access has been granted to you, you are acknowledging to utilize this elevated access for only necessary information, pertaining to your business functions or cases. This access will not be utilized for profit, or for reasons which do not apply to your work with the Court.

    Legacy Case index

    Legacy access is currently disabled.

title: Pay Traffic Fines
body:
Pay Traffic Fines

Shasta County Superior Court partners with Official Payments Corp® to offer traffic fine payments over the internet and by telephone. Visa®, MasterCard®, American Express®, and Discover® credit and debit cards are accepted. As the service provider, Official Payments charges a convenience fee for payment processing.

DO NOT PAY YOUR CITATION ONLINE:

IF YOU ARE CONSIDERING ATTENDING TRAFFIC SCHOOL,
IF YOU ARE CONTESTING YOUR CITATION, OR
IF YOUR CITATION INVOLVES A CORRECTABLE VIOLATION.

By paying online, you are WAIVING the option of Traffic School or Court Trial. Your case will be closed with a conviction immediately posted to your driving record. Refer to our Traffic Division web page for further details.

Your citation number is required to make payment in full online. Payments are also accepted via telephone by calling (530) 245-6789. You must know your citation/ticket number and submit your request any time prior to your appearance date to make payment using this service.

PLEASE NOTE: Monthly installment payments cannot be processed through this payment system at this time. If you wish to make a monthly payment, contact the Court Collections Division. If you wish to set up monthly payments, contact the Traffic Unit Clerk‘s Office. The minimum-allowed monthly payment is $50.00.

If your ticket was not issued within Shasta County, you may still be able to pay it online. Click the Official Payments link below for more information.


Online payments functionality is not available at this time, but will be enabled in the near future.

To pay your traffic ticket, you must mail the payment to the traffic clerk at the main courthouse building – 1500 Court Street, Redding, CA 96001. – Second Floor – Room 219, or physically see the clerk at the same location to perform the transaction.
